newsitem.title: USA: US Treasuries open narrowly lower before supply.
newsitem.headline: US Treasuries open narrowly lower before supply.

text.p: U.S. Treasury prices opened narrowly lower on Tuesday as players positioned themselves in front of new supply.
The Treasury will sell $18.25 billion in two-year notes this afternoon. The deadline for bids is 1300 EDT/1700 GMT.
Another $12.5 billion in securities -- this times five-year Treasury notes -- will be auctioned on Wednesday.
The market also gets two weekly reports on U.S. chain and department store sales.
The Bank of Tokyo/Mitsubishi survey of chain store sales, due at 0900 EDT/1300 GMT, is rumored to be up 0.8 percent.
"Such a strong report (would) put the market on the defensive early," said analysts at MMS International.
The Redbook chain store sales report is due at 1455 EDT/1855 GMT.
Other data on tap are not expected to move the market. The government will report September import and export prices. Those slipped 0.2 percent and 0.1 percent, respectively, in August.
September federal budget figures, due at 1400 EDT/1800 GMT, are expected to show a monthly budget surplus of $29.4 billion after a deficit of $41.83 billion in August.
In terms of data, the emphasis comes later this week with jobless claims data on Thursday and September durable orders figures on Friday, analysts said.

Even those data will not hold as much sway as the data that come next week, including the Employment Cost Index, the National Association of Purchasing Management (NAPM) index, third-quarter GDP and the October employment report, they said.
"Next week is littered with economic numbers, culminating in the (October) payroll numbers (on Friday)," said Steve Ricchuito, chief financial economist at BZW Securities.
But with new supply dominating the focus of Tuesday's trading session, the question is whether demand for the new Treasury notes will emerge at current levels, Ricchuito said.

"We've seen some fundamental decisions by some portfolio managers that they're less bullish than they had been," he said. "We're looking to see whether foreign buying materializes at these yield levels. Can we sell paper at these levels? If we can't, we might have a problem."
In when-issued trade early Tuesday, the two-year notes to be sold in the afternoon were yielding 5.925 percent. The five-year Treasury notes to be auctioned on Wednesday were yielding 6.265 percent.
Elsewhere, the 6-3/4 percent 30-year bond was down 4/32 to 99-5/32, yielding 6.87 percent.
Three-month bill rates were unchanged at five percent.
Six-month and year bill rates were each up one basis points to 5.13 percent and 5.25 percent, respectively.
The 6.5 percent ten-year note was down 3/32 to 99-25/32 to yield 6.53 percent. -- 212-859-1679
